New Scientist is reporting that soft tissue has been recovered from a femur of a 68 million year old T. rex. It was discovered after cracking open the bone in order to transport it.
 
 Is this discovery as important as it seems? Since there is no immediate audible buzz from the scientific community, maybe I'm overreacting.
 
 A couple thoughts:
 
 1. Do we now possess dinosaur DNA and what can we do with it? Haven't dinosaur bones been opened before?
 
 2. How does this play into the creationist's hands? I mean, I can already hear that soft tissue could possibly survive thousands of years, but millions?
 
 http://www.newscientist.com/article.ns?id=dn7195

New Scientist is reporting that soft tissue has been recovered from a femur of a 68 million year old T. rex. It was discovered after cracking open the bone in order to transport it.
 
 Is this discovery as important as it seems? Since there is no immediate audible buzz from the scientific community, maybe I'm overreacting.
 
 A couple thoughts:
 
 1. Do we now possess dinosaur DNA and what can we do with it? Haven't dinosaur bones been opened before?
 
 2. How does this play into the creationist's hands? I mean, I can already hear that soft tissue could possibly survive thousands of years, but millions?
 
 http://www.newscientist.com/article.ns?id=dn7195

 
 1. I think we now possess tissue that may yield some insight into dinosaur DNA, but I recall reading an article on this same discovery that says it will not yield a complete description of the DNA and that Jurasic Park is still out of reach.
 
 2. I think the creationists have little to celebrate here. Firstly, just because something seldom happens doesn't mean it never happens. The Ice Man proved that bodies can be nearly perfectly preserved without embalming fluids. Secondly, the softness of the tissue could have been revived by the soaking in fluids. Likely the tissue had been encapsulated for these millions of years and was not subject to extreme drying.
 
 "To see what remained of this internal structure, Schweitzer soaked samples of the core of the bone in a solution that dissolved the calcium compounds.  This left what she describes as "a flexible vascular tissue that demonstrates great elasticity and resilience". 
 
 For comparison, she then examined ostrich bones, as these birds are the largest and closest living relatives of T. rex. She found similar structures when she removed the calcium from the ostrich bones and treated the mixture with enzymes to break down collagen fibre in the bony matrix."
pandion

Well, it is pretty interesting.
 
 To answer your questions: There is no expectation that any DNA will be recovered. DNA does not preserve well. Even under perfect conditions, DNA degrades with time.
 
 Schweitzer repeated the work with other fossils - three times in fact. However, in every case, the samples were from large bones of large dinosaurs. Some of the structures that appear to be cells or even red blood cells, but it is not known what they are made of. One comment was that it would be mush in the shape of the cell. The article you linked says that traces of protein had been extracted from Iguanadon bone. Again, large bones from large animals. Prior to that there were what appeared to be red blood cells extracted from another T. rex (I think). In that case, all that remained was heme, and iron compound that makes up part of hemoglobin.
 
 Who knows what information they'll get from these samples.
 
 Of course, creationists claim that this means that the earth can't be old. These must be fossils that are only about 4,500 years old - died in the flood, you know.
 
 Carl Weiland of AIG in Australia (an M.D. by the way) wrote an article. An example of the great care creationists take in their research is Weiland's statement that Schweitzer is associated with "Montana University." There is no such place. Schweitzer is an assistant professor and researcher in molecular paleontology at N.C. State University. She was working at the Museum of the Rockies when she did this research. She had earned her Ph.D. from Montana State University in 1995.
 
 There was some speculation at the time of one of the previous finds about how the interior of a dinosaur bone could remain for millions of years without complete mineralization. I pointed out that all samples came from very large bones. What was suggested was that as the bone is mineralized from the outside in, the outer layers become impervious to water and thus seal the middle before it is completely mineralized. While the structures degrade, they are protected and remain in place.
 
 It's just another example of how creationists start from the conclusions and then selectively distort the evidence to support mythology.

supergrunt

Here is an interesting interview with one of the original scientists who identified the unknown soft tissue. I have to admit that I have not been keeping up with this story.. but as far as I am aware they have not yet confirmed any DNA proteins. Just de-calcified collagen and some soft of soft tissue associated with blood vessels.
 
 http://radio.cbc.ca/programs/quirks/archives/04-05/apr02.html#3
 
 The likelihood of DNA being recovered is pretty minuscule... but I think that the significance here is that what was previously considered too unstable to be preserved has been shown that under certain circumstances parts of soft tissue can be preserved for long periods.
 
 It is also important to understand that this tissue isn't really "dinosaur muscle".. it is the collagen within the bone and some sort of similar tissue associated with the blood vessels inside the bone.

It would not matter about how close dna was . A banana is 50% similar with humans, what is the significance of that fact?
The significance is that plants and animals share roughly 50% DNA. We can make further predictions that that 50% will be basic cell functionality related to respiration, DNA maintenance and replication, cell division etc.
 
 We can make a broad prediction that human DNA will be more closely related to all animals than to all plants (though this may not hold true of the likes of sponges, cnidaria, mosses and other 'simple' organisms) and that human DNA will be closer to a mouse or cow's DNA than a snake's and closer to a snake's than a toad's DNA. This prediction and the continual confirmation of it through DNA analysis is one of the two main branches of evidence that macro evolution is correct (the other bwing the fossil record). 
 
 
Are we half bannanas?
I'd hazard a guess that you are more than half actually.

I thought I would update this year-old thread because the predictions contained in it proved to be accurate (creationist would seize the opportunity to use soft tissue discovery as proof of a young earth). 
 
 Smithsonian magazine's May issue had a feature article on Mary Schweitzer, the paleotologist who discovered the soft tissue in a 68 million year old dinosaur. The article recounted her groundbreaking finding and provided an update of the latest research.
 
 But a clearly exasperated Schweizter is quoted as saying Christians have been treating her "really bad", accusing her of hiding the true meaning of her data. "They twist your words and they manipulate your data." Creation magazine claimed that her research was "powerful testimony against the whole idea of dinosaurs living millions of years ago. It speaks volumes for the Bible account of a recent creation".
 
 It's worth noting that Schweitzer identifies herself as a Christian, not some evil atheistic scientist, and she appears to be quite perplexed by the whole affair. Someone should have warned her.
